doc.after: Public transport is provided by the Kolkata Suburban Railway, the Kolkata Metro, trams, and buses. The suburban rail network reaches the city's distant suburbs. According to a 2013 survey conducted by International Association of Public Transport, Kolkata ranks the top among the six cities surveyed in India, in terms of public transport system.[142][143] The Kolkata Metro, in operation since 1984, is the oldest underground mass transit system in India.[144] It spans the northâsouth length of the city and covers a distance of 25.1Â km (16Â mi).[145] As of 2009[update], five Metro rail lines were under construction.[146] Kolkata has four long-distance railway stations, located at Howrah (the largest railway complex in India), Sealdah, Chitpur and Shalimar, which connect Kolkata by rail to most cities in West Bengal and to other major cities in India.[147] The city serves as the headquarters of three railway Zone out of Seventeen of the Indian Railways regional divisionsâthe Kolkata Metro Railways, Eastern Railway and the South-Eastern Railway.[148]
